Problem:
Consider a complex function defined by \\( z(t) = e^{i \\omega t} \\), representing a signal in the complex plane with angular frequency \\( \\omega \\). We analyze the effect of a Fourier transform \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) \\) on this function.

If a frequency shift operation \\( z(t) \\to z(t) \\cdot e^{i \\delta t} \\), where \\( \\delta \\) is a constant, is applied before taking the Fourier transform, will the result \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) \\) be affected?
Explanation: The intervention of frequency shifting \\( z(t) \\) by \\( \\delta \\) results in a new signal \\( z(t) \\cdot e^{i \\delta t} = e^{i (\\omega + \\delta) t} \\). The Fourier transform will now peak at \\( \\omega + \\delta \\), thus shifting the position of the delta function in the frequency domain, indicating a direct effect of the intervention on the transform result.
